Sun of Faith - English: Chapter 6: The Birth at Lumbini
Thus the Bodhisattva spent ten moons in his noble mother's womb.
Manual - Tibetan (བོད་ཡིག།): ཁང་བཟང་དེ་དང་མ་འབྲེལ་བར་བར་སྟོང་ཡོད་ཙམ་དུ་གཞན་ཞིག་ཏུ། ལུམ་བུའི་ཚལ་དེ་སྐྱེད་མོས་ཚལ་ཤིང་སྣ་ཚོགས་ཡོད་པ་གཅིག་བྱ། དེ་ན་འཁོར་མང་པོས་སྐོར་ནས། རང་ཡུམ་ཉིད་ཁྱོགས་བྱམས་ཁྲི་ལ་གཡོག་མ་འགའ་རེ་དང་བཅས་པ་ལུམྦི་ནའི་ཚལ་དུ་འབྱོན་པའི་ཚུལ་དང་། ཚལ་དེར་སྐུ་བལྟམས་པའི་བཀོད་པ་སྤྱི་དང་འདྲ་བ་ལས། ནམ་མཁའ་ནས་ཆུ་རྒྱུན་གཉིས་དབུའི་སྟེང་དུ་འབབ་པ་དང་། ལྷ་རྣམས་ཀྱི་གདུགས་དང་རྔ་ཡབ་ལ་སོགས་པ་མཆོད་པ་སྣ་ཚོགས་པ་འབུལ་ཞིང་།  ཚལ་དེའི་ཕྱི་ནང་ཐམས་ཅད་འོད་ཀྱི་ཁྱབ་པ་མཚོན་བྱེད་དུ། ཕྱི་ནས་འོད་ཀྱི་དཀྱིལ་འཁོར་ཟླུམ་པོས་སྐོར་བ་འབྲི། དེ་དང་ཉེ་བའི་ཕྱོགས་རྣམས་སུ། རྒོད་མ་རྟེའུ་འབྲེང་པ་མང་པོ་དང་། གླང་ཆེན་མོ་ཕྲུག་གུ་འབྲེང་བ། བུད་མེད་ཁྱེའུ་དང་བུ་མོ་ཐོགས་པ་དང་། ས་འོག་ནས་རིན་པོ་ཆེའི་གཏེར་ཁ་བྱེ་བ་རྣམས་ལྔ་བརྒྱ་མཚོན་བྱེད། ལྔ་ཙམ་རེ་འབྲི།
Manual - English: In the open space near the mansion is Lumbini Grove (lum bu’i tshal / lum+bi ni’i tshal), a garden with a great array of trees. A large retinue is there. The queen sits in a palanquin and goes to Lumbini Grove with her entourage of maids. The birth of the Buddha takes place in the grove. The scenes should be drawn in accord with common conventions (spyi dang ‘dra ba). But, there should be two streams of water flow down onto the head. Gods offer many gifts such as parasols and tail fans. Light fills up both inside and outside of the grove. A ring of light surrounds the grove. Nearby is a scene of mares followed by colts, elephants with cubs, and women with baby boys and girls.  Five kinds of treasures are drawn to make up for deposits of five hundred kinds of treasures uncovered in the ground. In another mansion, (representatives of) vassals prostrate and offer gifts to King Śuddhodana.

Sun of Faith - English: It was the first few days of the last spring month, and the trees and flowers were basking in the sun, the air was pleasant with birdsong, and the mango trees were weighted down with ripe fruit.
[That day] Queen Mahamayadevi felt like visiting the parks of Devadaha, her own birthplace.
She said as much to King Shuddhodana, who at once ordered his people to make arrangements for an excursion to a place called Lumbini, near Devadaha.
Then he requested the queen to climb into a wooden palanquin studded with jewels.
With the escort of the king and all the king's soldiers, the palanquin—further attended by a bevy of ladies-in-waiting—
left Kapilavastu and took the road to Lumbini.
Certain sutras date the birth of the Buddha from the eighth day of the moon, at first light, when the sun is in the constellation Victory (end of December or January).
When Mahamaya-devi reached the grounds, she took a good look round and feeling that the momentous event was near, directed her steps towards a flower-laden ashoka tree.
The tree leaned towards the queen. Raising her right arm, she held fast onto one of its branches, desiring to give birth.
In order to spare the modest queen from the stares of the soldiers, Indra raised a violent storm and the men, surprised by gusts of rain, fled.
Inscription - English: Indra raised a violent wind and rain storm upon the men

Sun of Faith - English: The lord of the gods alone, in the guise of an aged midwife, stayed with the queen.
The Bodhisattva came into this world without causing a single twinge of pain to his mother:
he emerged from her right thigh without making more of an effort than one makes to open a door, go through it and shut it behind one.
Mahamaya-devi's body showed no traces of scar or strain.
Scene working notes: This is not in either of the accounts (Abhiniṣkramaṇa-sūtra Vinayavastu: Saṃghabhedavastu)

Sun of Faith - English: The lord of the gods would have liked to receive the newborn wrapped in the softest of deerskins,
and so in order to pacify Indra's arrogance [implied by such a wish] , the Bodhisattvas body was transformed into an adamantine body and,
unable to hold him, Indra started to shake.
The Bodhisattva cried out: “Kaushika, leave me be!”
Thereupon, in order to be modestly adorned and not naked, the Bodhisattva was born draped in celestial robes.
Immediately after the Bodhisattva came out of his mother, the earth shuddered six times
Scene working notes: The Vinayavastu source mearly mentions that the earth shakes with mention of how many times: "sa chen po 'di yang g.yos par gyur" (280b.1-2)

Sun of Faith - English: and a great radiance filled the entire universe.
That instant the child took seven steps towards the east and uttered these words:
“This is where the sun begins to rise. I will begin by rising beyond suffering.”
Then he took seven steps towards the south and said: “This is where the sun reaches its highest point. I will be looked up to by all living beings.”
Walking towards the west, he declared: “This is where the sun sets. This lifetime will be the last of my rebirths."
Finally he walked towards the north and affirmed: “And here is the cold and distant direction called the north. And I, in this one lifetime, will traverse the ocean of existence."
From above, the gods poured over the Bodhisattva two streams of water, one warm, one cool, to rinse his body.
Inscription - English: The gods bathe him and make offerings

Sun of Faith - English: They presented him with a white parasol, a yaktail fly-whisk, incense, flowers and clothes.
Scene working notes: In the Vinayavastu passage, the white parasol and (two) "jewel-handled yaktail fly wisks," are not given to the Bodhisattva, but, rahter, held over his head: "de'i dbu'i steng nas lha rnams gdugs dkar po dang / rnga yab nor bu'i yu ba can dag 'dzin to/" (280b.6)

Sun of Faith - English: The whole sky throbbed to the sound of invisible cymbals.
A large basin of clear water appeared before the Bodhisattva's mother—who could thus wash and refresh herself.
Inscription - English: The mother bathes in a spring

Sun of Faith - English: The radiance which flooded the world on the birth of the Bodhisattva even penetrated deep into the cave hidden on the slopes of Mount Sandhara (Kun 'dzin), where the sage Asita was sitting in meditation, along with his nephew and disciple, Naradatta (Mi byin).
Scene working notes: In the Vinayavastu passage there is no mention of "meditation" per se, although it describes them as: " 'jig pa la mkhas pa/ 'chags pa la mkhas pa zhig gnas te/" (280a.7-281b.1)

Sun of Faith - English: Seeing their cave become suffused with light, Naradatta cried:
“One would imagine that all the suns of the universe had taken to rising in unison.
What's going on, uncle?”
Asita intoned: "The sun's rays always have something too fiery about them;
Whereas this intense light, my son,
It slides, cool and lovely, across the skin.
Surely it originates from a powerful being."
Naradatta wanted to rush off that very moment to seek out the Bodhisattva, but his uncle reasoned with him:
“Right now it is the kings of the skies, far greater beings than us, who are around the Bodhisattva;
we won't be able to get anywhere near him.
As soon as he reaches Kapilavastu, then we'll go and pay homage.”
On the day of the prince's birth, each of the kings of the regions of the east, south, west and north had a son.
Not dreaming that the wonderful glow the world was awash in could be caused by anything other than the birth of their own sons,
King Mahapadma (Padma chen po) of Magadha named his son ‘Essence of Form’, or Bimbisara (Gzugs can snying po);
Mahakoshala, king of Shravasti (Mnyan yod) called his ‘Light Ever-increasing’, or Prasenajit (Gsal rgyal);
the son of Shatanika (Dmag brgya) from Kaushambi (Mdzod ldan) received the name ‘Rising Sun’, or Udayana (Shar pa);
and the child of King Anantanemi (Mu khyud mtha' yas) of Ujjayini ('Phags rgyal) was called Prince Dazzling, Pradyota (Rab snang).
Thus, each gave their offspring a name whose meaning reflected that omnipresent light.
In the Shakya clan, five hundred girls and five hundred boys—of whom one was given the name Bhadrika (Bzang ldan)—saw the light of day at the same time as the Bodhisattva.
No less than five hundred sons—one being the child Chandaka (Mdun pa)—were born to the king's attendants, while Sabha (Mdun ma) and five hundred daughters were born to the ladies-in-waiting.
Also on this day five hundred she-elephants calved, five hundred mares foaled,
Inscription - English: Babies were born to five hundred she-elephants, five hundred mares, and five hundred she-camels

Sun of Faith - English: five hundred treasures were discovered
and all the vassal kings appeared at the palace to pay tribute.
Inscription - English: The vassal kings pay tribute Shuddhodana

Sun of Faith - English: “Well, well,” King Shuddhodana exulted, “With the birth of my son, all my wishes have been fulfilled. So I shall call him Siddhartha, the Wishfulfilling One.” And Siddhartha was his name.
